title: British expats in Gibraltar stage huge anti-Brexit protest as they slam the PM's 'terrible deal'
text:
British expats in Spain have staged a huge anti-Brexit protest, slamming Boris Johnson's 'terrible' deal and calling for a second referendum.

More than 2,000 people took to the streets of La Línea de la Concepción, near the border of British overseas territory Gibraltar, to voice their anger about the supposed negative effects of the UK's withdrawal from the EU on southern Spain.

Protesters claimed Brexit would be dangerous for Britons and Spaniards in Spain - should the Prime Minister stick to his 'do or die' pledge to leave by October 31.

'Brexit is already having an effect,' British expat Lucy, 63, told MailOnline.

More than 2,000 people took to the streets of La Línea de la Concepción, near the border of British overseas territory Gibraltar to protest on Saturday

Protesters were voicing their anger about the negative effects of the UK's withdrawal from the EU on southern Spain

Several organisations joined together to march under the banner 'for a humanitarian border' at the protest, including organising group, the Sociocultural Association of Spanish Workers in Gibraltar (pictured, protesters near the Gibraltar border on Saturday)

Pro-European and pan-European federalist political political party Volt was also at the protest (pictured protesters on Saturday)

The 63-year-old and resident of Jimena de la Frontera said she was 'worried about the effects of Brexit on Gibraltar.

She said: 'Already Bet365 in Gibraltar has left for Malta. There's so little that's decided. We don't know for certain that Brexit is going to happen but it's likely.'

Her friend Fran, 62, said they had come to protest 'to support the local people that Brexit affects.'

'Lots of British people live here and work in Gibraltar because it's cheaper here,' she added.

'I worry about what will happen to La Linea, because business with Gibraltar has given it a boost.'

Pro-European and pan-European federalist political political party Volt was also at the protest.

Its Spanish board member Ana Rosada said: 'The old conflicts that were pacified by the EU are going to resurface.

'Volt are supporting the people of Gibraltar who are going to be isolated.

'We think Boris Johnson's deal is a terrible deal and hope for a second referendum.

'But even if the UK does leave the EU on October 31, we hope it returns.

'There are a lot of British people living in Spain, it is a big deal for them.

'Also, this is 2019 and it makes no sense for us to be divided.'

The Rock of Gibraltar is visible in the background as thousands of protesters take to the streets to voice their anger at the Prime Minister's Brexit deal

One protester claimed that cross-border workers would be stuck in six-hour queues, adding that the customs officials on both sides make it difficult to cross (pictured, protesters near Gibraltar on Saturday)

The march was also attended by the mayors of La Linea, San Roque and Los Barrios, Juan Franco, Juan Carlos Ruiz Boix and Miguel Alconchel, respectively (pictured, protesters on Saturday)

Spanish board member of Volt Ana Rosada said: 'The old conflicts that were pacified by the EU are going to resurface. Volt are supporting the people of Gibraltar who are going to be isolated'

Several organisations joined together to march under the banner 'for a humanitarian border' at the protest, including organising group, the Sociocultural Association of Spanish Workers in Gibraltar (ASCTEG).

Its leader Juan Jose Uceda gave a rousing speech and said that the Brexit deal currently being negotiated by Mr Johnson was 'dangerous' for the UK and Spain.

The Spaniard, from La Linea, added: 'Brexit is such a stupid idea, when you have the safety of the EU, why would you create something so dangerous?

'People in the UK were lied to by politicians about their social security etc. during the EU referendum.'

Uceda also claimed that cross-border workers would be stuck in six-hour queues, adding that the customs officials on both sides make it difficult to cross.

'I know people who leave for work at 4:30 in the morning to get to Gibraltar.

'The customs officials stop people capriciously and randomly for sovereignty reasons.'

The protests (pictured) come as the Commons yesterday voted 322 to 306 in favour of an amendment postponing a decision on the PM's deal

The vote activated the Benn Act - a Remainer law that compels Mr Johnson to send a letter by midnight asking Brussels for a delay (pictured, protesters in Gibraltar on Saturday)

After suffering an embarrassing defeat in the Commons over his Brexit plans, the Prime Minister got a senior diplomat to send an unsigned photocopy of the call by MPs to delay withdrawal from the bloc (pictured, a protester in Gibraltar)

The march was also attended by the mayors of La Linea, San Roque and Los Barrios, Juan Franco, Juan Carlos Ruiz Boix and Miguel Alconchel, respectively.

Across the border, Fabian Picardo was re-elected as Gibraltar Chief Minister for the third time on Thursday.

The Rock's leader, whose territory voted overwhelmingly to remain in the EU, has pledged to cooperate with the UK Government on Brexit.

It comes as the Commons yesterday voted 322 to 306 in favour of an amendment postponing a decision on the PM's deal, and activating the Benn Act - a Remainer law that compels him to send a letter by midnight asking Brussels for a delay.

After suffering an embarrassing defeat in the Commons over his Brexit plans, the Prime Minister got a senior diplomat to send an unsigned photocopy of the call by MPs to delay withdrawal from the bloc.

In a second note to European Council president Donald Tusk, the PM said a Brexit extension would be 'deeply corrosive'.

The stance is likely to spark a fierce political row.
description: More than 2,000 people took to the streets of La Línea de la Concepción, near the border of British overseas territory Gibraltar, to voice their anger about the supposed negative effects of Brexit.
